title: Open Redirect in Logout & Login

profile.name: Expedia Group Bug Bounty
profile.about: Expedia Group is the world’s travel platform, with an extensive brand portfolio that includes some of the world’s most trusted online travel brands.

vulnerability_information:
## Entry
Hello there! While browsing on expedia, I logged out of the account and as soon as I logged out, it was calling me a parameter called "rurl" directly on the link, I examined it and was able to redirect successfully.

## Default Request

GET /?logout=1 HTTP/2
Host: www.expedia.com
Cookie:  { REDACTED }
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64; rv:107.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/107.0
Accept: text/html,application/xhtml+xml,application/xml;q=0.9,image/avif,image/webp,*/*;q=0.8
Accept-Language: tr-TR,tr;q=0.8,en-US;q=0.5,en;q=0.3
Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate
Upgrade-Insecure-Requests: 1
Sec-Fetch-Dest: document
Sec-Fetch-Mode: navigate
Sec-Fetch-Site: none
Sec-Fetch-User: ?1
Te: trailers

## Default Response

HTTP/2 200 OK

##In response, it redirects us to the homepage.

## Vulnerability Request

GET /?logout=https://qx4lw1nsec.blogspot.com HTTP/2
Host: www.expedia.com
Cookie: { REDACTED }
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64; rv:107.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/107.0
Accept: text/html,application/xhtml+xml,application/xml;q=0.9,image/avif,image/webp,*/*;q=0.8
Accept-Language: tr-TR,tr;q=0.8,en-US;q=0.5,en;q=0.3
Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate
Upgrade-Insecure-Requests: 1
Sec-Fetch-Dest: document
Sec-Fetch-Mode: navigate
Sec-Fetch-Site: none
Sec-Fetch-User: ?1
Te: trailers


## Note
The part that exposes to explicit redirection is "?" in the section after the address. is use.
and whatever he does he will throw redirects.

## Video
{F2053834}

## Impact

Redirect
Phishing
Social Engineering

activities.message:
Hi @qualwin3001,

Thank you for your submission. I hope you are well. Your report is currently being reviewed and the HackerOne triage team will get back to you once there is additional information to share.

Have a great day! 

Kind regards,
@h1_analyst_jan

Hello @qualwin3001 - Please provide a working PoC link that, when clicked by the victim, triggers the issue you reported against them. Having to replace the value of `rurl` manually via proxy would make this a self attack and would require MITM for an attacker to leverage the issue.

We would love to take another look at your report once you have provided additional information supporting your issue.

Regards,
@h1_analyst_jan

## Entry
The problem to be explained here is this: https://example.com/"?"
The question mark in quotation marks causes redirection and different problems as an example.

## Firstly :

Go to expedia home page and address: ** /?https://evil.com/ **
or 
** /?logout=https://evil.com/ **

You can write.

## Secondly :

** Click on the right to enter your expedia account and you will be redirected as soon as you click. **

this self is not a clear direction. It is a straight direction. It directs you directly, you may not have noticed it in the video, but I will explain it in more detail.

## Firstly Request

GET /?logout=https://evil.com HTTP/2
Host: www.expedia.com
Cookie: █████████
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64; rv:107.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/107.0
Accept: text/html,application/xhtml+xml,application/xml;q=0.9,image/avif,image/webp,*/*;q=0.8
Accept-Language: tr-TR,tr;q=0.8,en-US;q=0.5,en;q=0.3
Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate
Upgrade-Insecure-Requests: 1
Sec-Fetch-Dest: document
Sec-Fetch-Mode: navigate
Sec-Fetch-Site: none
Sec-Fetch-User: ?1
Te: trailers

## Firstly Response

Since the answer is too long, I can't assign it. In the search section, write the site address after the "logout" parameter.

{F2055638}
{F2055639}

## Secondly Request

GET /login?ckoflag=0&uurl=e3id%3Dredr%26rurl%3D%2F HTTP/2
Host: www.expedia.com
Cookie: █████████
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64; rv:107.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/107.0
Accept: text/html,application/xhtml+xml,application/xml;q=0.9,image/avif,image/webp,*/*;q=0.8
Accept-Language: tr-TR,tr;q=0.8,en-US;q=0.5,en;q=0.3
Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate
Referer: https://www.expedia.com/
Upgrade-Insecure-Requests: 1
Sec-Fetch-Dest: document
Sec-Fetch-Mode: navigate
Sec-Fetch-Site: same-origin
Sec-Fetch-User: ?1
Te: trailers

** rurl is encoded : rurl%3d%2f%3flogout%3dhttps%3a%2f%2fqx4lw1nsec.blogspot.com **
** decoded : rurl=/?logout=https://qx4lw1nsec.blogspot.com **

## Secondly Response

Since the answer is too long, I can't assign it. In the search section, write the site address after the "logout" parameter.

{F2055634}

## Description

This is the first time I've encountered such a redirect and of course you didn't understand it, but you have to do it the way I did in the video. and a redirect will appear as a result.

## Video 2

{F2055647}

Hi @qualwin3001,

On trying to reproduce this issue, I still do not receive the get request to the redirect endpoints eg, `evil.com`. I also noticed that the redirect in your PoC the redirect did not work for the endpoint `evil.com` instead it worked for the endpoint `https://qx4lw1nsec.blogspot.com`. Could you please clarify this behaviour? 

Ideally, open redirects should have a PoC which on click redirects you from the vulnerable page to the attacker hosted page but in this case there seems to be a requirement for additional unlikely user interaction and are considered `Informative` findings. 

If you could demonstrate the redirect without the use of additional user interaction eg. Burp intercept, please add an updated PoC.

I would love to take another look at your report once you have provided additional information supporting your issue.

Cheers,
@h1_analyst_jan

If you try it on Mozilla it will redirect, it's not Mozilla's vulnerability, it can only be solved by configuring the sites. No such redirect is seen on any other site. so this is only visible on Expedia.
So if a person with an expedia account uses mozilla, I can easily redirect that person to my malicious site, moreover, in a very easy and difficult way.

there is also a possibility that the redirect here causes a cross site scripting vulnerability. because when I check the references there are many reports like this and it will just have to bypass the akamai firewall. security researchers offer this by sharing, but I haven't been able to get it yet.

but we know that redirecting is dangerous, moreover, redirect it directly, I think it may be high in severity.

Referer : https://hackerone.com/reports/683298

As you can see on the reference, there is a login page and a cross site scripting code is added and executed on the parameter on the address, I am not sure, but of course I think it can be.

That's why I see its severity as high.

Hey @qualwin3001,

Thank you for your report!

The reported behaviour was not reproducible on our end as well as by the program team.  As a result, with confirmation from the teams end, we will be closing this report as informative. If you are able to leverage this behaviour any further, we will be happy to reevaluate this report.

This will not have any impact on your Signal or Reputation score. We appreciate your effort and look forward to seeing more reports from you in the future.

Kind regards,
@h1_analyst_jan

I'm not in favor of closing it as informative,

Looking at the policy section, it does not say that the open redirect vulnerability is not accepted, and there is a vulnerability on the site that leads to direct redirection, we know very well that this can have a high impact on phishing and social engineering.

In my references:
yes, this is given as an acceptable situation.

It seems very unusual for the expedia team to leave this gap as informative in my opinion.

## if you need more details;
You can see that there is a redirect here when you use "Firefox".
You know that there are and will be many users who use "Firefox" when logging into expedia. no user is aware of this security vulnerability, this redirect will seem normal to them.

when I tried this on my friend personally i.e.:
When I sent it to the address that was forwarding, it logged out of my friend's account and directed it to the site I specified.

Do you think this is informative? users' security is at stake.

Kind regards.
@qualwin3001

and I will explain the reason for the vulnerability, it would be nice if you fix it. I think it's a big configuration error.

## Fix the Vulnerability

Let's go to expedia using chrome and see why the redirect is not occurring.
{F2064807}

As you can see, the parameters are configured with the "url encode" method, so a redirect does not occur on chrome.

## what about on Firefox?

When we try it on Firefox, we see that the "url encode" method is not configured.
The reason for the weakness appears above.
phishing attacks or social engineering attacks can be carried out.
once again i think the impact can be medium to high
{F2064810}

And if I have to say;

All sites within scope currently have this open redirect vulnerability. I still think it's important and it works on separate parameters.

for example: the question mark after the address part; You know that partnerAdress=https://phishing-site.com/ can be written.

"?" to remove it. sign should cease to function. Note that it is not configured for mozilla.

Screenshot :

{F2065779}
{F2065782}

## I also have some new news. 

We used to redirect on Firefox, now we can run it on Chrome. How Does ? then watch the video, if you see fit, we can pass on all the details.
this now works on all scopes!

## Description
If you need more clarification: we've now been able to redirect you on google and you know it's even more dangerous. we were able to run it on only 2 addresses on the affected addresses
but when you try it on Firefox it works on all addresses.

current target : when you go directly to the login page and log in, the redirect will occur.

- Now let's create an attack scenario first

When you send the given link to a user, the "url encode" operation will not occur. but if this person goes to login himself then the "url encode" process comes into play. but this will not happen in the link I will give and it will provide direct guidance from the moment he logs in.

yes, things seem more important now :)

## affected addresses
https://www.expedia.com/
https://www.vrbo.com/

## Video
{F2065835}

For example, a security measure should be taken, such as this address. For the 2 addresses I mentioned above
{F2065864}

but on Firefox you can overcome this because the parameter on the homepage directly ignores it and redirects it.

So I can say that I have found 2 types of redirects at the moment.

1- Forwarding via parameter [Firefox]
2- redirect by disabling url encode method [Firefox,Chrome]
Update?
Any Update?

I think the level of vulnerability has increased. When I check it, when you log in via "Google", I can directly direct you to the site I specified.

Will there be no updates? You need to evaluate.

Hi @qualwin3001, 

Thank you for the additional information. The team has been able to validate your finding although this might be a duplicate. We have forwarded the report over to them. They will let us know the final ruling on this report. Please note that the status and severity are subject to change.

Thanks,
@h1_analyst_jan
is there an update now?
update?
update?
Update?
Thank you very much for the submission, @qualwin3001 . Happy hacking!
Report has passed initial validation and is pending resolution. Please note that the status and severity are subject to change.
Thanks
H1 Retest requested.

my tests show that the redirection is still working.
I also saw that routing can be done when registering.

Register Redirect : https://www.expedia.com/signup?enable_registration=true&+=&uurl=e3id%3Dredr%26rurl=qx4lw1nsec.blogspot.com@qx4lw1nsec.blogspot.com

Video below.
